last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14999562
infinity is not a properly defined notion. Morever, the operation of division is not clearly defined for division by zero. Division by definition is the inverse operation of multiplication:

If x/0 = y, then x = 0*y = 0. If x is assumed non-zero, then we have a contradiction so the statement x/0 =y can only be considered meaningful if x=0. However 0/0 =y is true for any y. Hence the operation of division by zero is not well-defined.

The expression "1/0" is therefore nonsense.

The answer you're really looking for is that the first principles of every branch of physics are set in such a way that everything else can be defined in terms of what the first principles allow there to be.
There's no turtles at the bottom, no escape from the Matrix, no world outside of the cave, nothing else.
They're all just names for variables and functions that we consistently assign to phenomena that match a certain set of criteria. We use them because they preserve a certain mathematical relation between each other.
There is no scientific answer to any question that starts with "why". There are only answers to questions asking for "how" and "by what means" things come to be, given some constraints that we must either measure or assume if not given.

last_replies.com: P=NP, computation can't create information. You don't need quantum anything. All factoring can be done once you learn maths better.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14998991
Seems like you're assuming they'd only be able to do this for newly signed transactions, but it's more than that: they could crack any private key (that's using elliptic curve crypto), and steal from any wallet. Or more generally, send any transaction signed by an arbitrary address. If a powerful enough QC comes around, every crypto that's still on elliptic curves drops to 0 overnight.
Much more likely though that cryptography will progress to (presumably) quantum-safe protocols before QC hardware reaches those levels.

threads.com:
Been learning measure theory and the Caratheodory trick of measurable sets is just amazing
> Take any set and any outer measure defined on this set. Then the collection of measurable sets (in the sense of caratheodory) not only forms a sigma algebra, but the outer measure restricted on these measurable sets (the new sigma algebra) satisfies the properties of a true measure.
a really profound theorem, since the outer measure is nearly perfect and satisfies many desired properties, but is sadly not countably additive (only subadditive). you can also complete existing measure spaces by adding null sets
> Take a measure defined on a sigma algebra, and extend the sigma algebra by forming all sets that are a union of a set from the sigma algebra with a null set (a null set is a subset of a set with measure zero). This new collection is a sigma algebra, which contains the original sigma algebra plus all the null sets. Defining a new measure which preserves the mapping of the old one when restricted to the original sigma algebra, will still be a measure on the new collection. This new measure space is complete, meaning every set contained in a null set will also be part of the collection.
what this entails is that one may add 'negligible' null sets to a measure space without sacrificing any meaningful properties of the measure space. This is precisely what differs the borel sigma algebra on the real line from the lebesgue measurable sets, and completing the borel algebra leads to the lebesgue measurable sets. On both sets one has a measure, which is nearly the same. Most sets one has to deal with are borel sets, but this is no problem since the extended measure does not measure the 'size' if the sets any larger.
Share your favourite measure theory facts here.

threads.com:
/x/ adjacent question here about the information content of script using a cypher.

Gematria, a "sub-discipline" of Kabbalah is a type of numerology. Hebrew letters have numeric values and words with the same sum can be linked together.

Methods go way deeper than simple addition and can be recursive and involve combinatorics. The first use of graph theory seems like it might have come from Kabbalah.

Anyhow, use of these techniques are said to allow the adept to find hidden messages in the Bible. Essentially, the text is in cypher and mathematics allows you to unlock the cypher.

There are tons of commentaries on these. What makes it interesting from a /sci/ perspective is the question, what then in the information content of the Bible? (Ignoring lame answers like how many bits it takes up on a hard drive).

The methods aren't random and subjective. Kabbalahists using the same system get the same relationships between words, although sometimes the meanings rely on a lot of interpretation.

Since you can transform the values of the letters in infinite ways, it would appear you can generate an infinite amount of messages from the finite text. But what does that mean for the idea of the information content of messages?

This differs from the more down to Earth example of someone transmitting a message in such a way that it has 4 coherent meanings in 4 different known codes. In that case, we can still use the total number of characters in the string and raise it to the nth power, where n = the number of possible characters, for a measure of information. However, once you start allowing mathematical manipulations of the string, it seems like the sky is the limit.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
The human internal clock runs slow, typically on a 25-26 hour cycle. In order to synchronize to the 24-hour day-night cycle, our body recieves external cues to advance (shorten) or delay (extend) our internal clocks and stay synchronized with the sun. These cues, typically light and melatonin levels, are called "zeitgebers" and can cause an advance or delay in our circadian cycle depending on the time of day.

Melatonin is commonly prescribed for people with DSPD ("late risers") and N24SWD. The instruction is usually to take it in the evening, but based on this Phase Response Curve (PRC), wouldn't you want to take it at lunch instead? Assuming you naturally wake up at 8am, this graph indicates that just before 1pm would be the best time to advance your sleep cycle, and that any later you risk having residual melatonin levels in the evening, causing a delay.

Likewise, shouldn't bright light exposure start 2-3 hours /before/ you wake up, since that's where the peak is?

Sleep cycle/chronobiology thread go

I was reading that, according to physics, computation doesn't generate new information.

How can this be? Isn't this how zip bombs worked? You fill a text filed with 10 billion zeros and then compress the shit out of it. Because the entire file is just one character 10 billion times, it can be written using a really small amount of code.

However, when anti-virus software attempts to open the file, it begins to decompress it. This fills the memory, freezing it up. Wouldn't this be creating information?

Also, running computers creates a fuck ton of heat. More heat = more physical entropy = more possible states the enviornment can be in. So, by this logic, yes aren't computers always generating heat because they are generating entropy? And if more entropy = more information needed to describe a physical system, this makes sense.

If not, why does it work that way?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15000435
you're not really creating information out of nothing. You're using electricity to rearrange the magnetic configuration of a hard disk, or adding/removing charges in the case of flash memory.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15000818
More information is required to describe a system as entropy increases.

Recall how information content is measured in Shannon's entropy and it is obvious that this requires that the information content goes up, since more is required before uncertainty is reduced to 0 about all random variables.

>>15000447
How information is defined is a huge problem for the sciences. You have information theoretical approaches becoming core to every field under the sun but then information theory courses might only show up in an electrical engineering catalog, with maybe one course at a school.

This is why there is so much confusion. People also use a lot of use case specific examples and confuse people.

They hear explanations of thermodynamics entropy in terms of information and see the formulae are almost identical and confuse them. I know I have.

The key is that thermodynamic entropy uses the Boltzmann distribution for states. Shannon Entropy has no probability distribution. It's essentially combinatorial. If I can use 26 letters in a message plus spaces, I have 27 possible values for X for real character. A string of length 100 then has 27^100 possible values.

The problem is that when this is taught, you almost always jump right from this to talking about how the letter E appears 57 times more often than Q and that the probability distribution is based on frequency in the English language (frequentism strikes again). Letters in a message also contain mutual information. You learn this because knowing the probability distribution for your variable let's you create a code that uses less bits to code the data. However it confuses people into thinking that for every use case there is some objective "real" distribution for measuring information content.

There isn't. Check out the Gibbs paradox. Even thermodynamic entropy is subjective (but not arbitrary).

Deterministic computation does not create new information about the source of the data.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15001161
>Deterministic computation does not create new information about the source of the data.

Is what is meant. Obviously if you expand a compressed file and it is using a given amount of memory you are generating heat to get rid of that information (Landauer's Principal). If it isn't information wtf is this?

If a professor has a computer deterministically create a probability distribution using a pseudorandom number generator, we'd generally say no information is being created. However, if he sends the data set on to his students, he is clearly sending information, and if they randomly sample the data they get information.

Because Shannon's entropy is so broadly applicable, people get confused about how to apply it.

There is actually another level of confusion with codes. I can have the same string represent different messages using different codes. If my message goes to two different receivers, each set up to use one of the different codes, did they also receive the other message too?

OP here, while the answer is most probably correct (i didn't check it, it's not that important to me) i don't think your approach is very proof driven.

I think the most important relation to consider is the following:
given [math]a,b,e,f \in \mathbb{N}[/math] and [math]ab+ef=A[/math], then if we let [math]af+eb=B[/math] it follows that [math]B=a[b+(f-b)]+e[f+(b-f)][/math], that is [math]B=A+a(f-b)-e(f-b)[/math].
This tells us that if a>b then B is greater than A IF and ONLY IF f>b. In other words exchanging two numbers between the terms of the addition will increase the result IF and ONLY IF we are moving the smaller number from the term where the remaining factors multiply to [math]a[/math] to the term where they multiply to [math]b[/math].

I will keep posting to explain how this can be used to our advantage.

threads.com: Is there an objective unit of time, not based on Earth or the sun, that we can measure time in?

last_replies.name: An idiot
last_replies.com:
>>14998062, Not quite, there would no effect on the number of cycles of radiation due to changes in temperature or magnetic field. Even at absolute zero or in the middle of the sun. It'd make it more or less likely for the transition to happen, but once that transition happens the amount of time that passes would be the same for both. Idk if this has been experimentally verified, this is just based on what I know, and I'm happy to be proven wrong so lemme know if you find anything.

You're right that the strength of gravity and velocity relative to the speed of light would cause a difference, but the definition of 1 second would remain the same. It's just that 1 second can vary from one place to another. Usually by a very miniscule amount, so little that being in orbit for years only leads to a difference of microseconds, but 1 second orbiting a black hole would be significantly longer compared to 1 second on earth. How significant would depend on how big the black hole is, and how close you're orbiting. As far as we know, a living creature would still only experience 1 second no matter what, but if you're orbiting a black hole then 1 second for you could be equal to hours, days, even months on earth.

TL;DR Watch Interstellar

ct is the vector that results from adding vt. If d/t=c relative to someone moving at the same speed relative to the clock, then an outside observer measuring the clock sees (d+x)/t=c where x is the speed of the clock relative to the observer. Yes the distance is different but it doesn't change the speed of light. 2/1=2, (2+2)/1=4 map this to the equation and notice a change in distance implies a change in speed, but the speed of light cannot change.
